abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Secondary Education
            Enhancement Project (SEEP) for Egypt were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was high, the Bank performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            also moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: in this first venture into the secondary education
            subsector, goals for change in content and processes should
            have been much more modest. Project teams and sector
            management need to resist the temptation to try to fix all
            problems in a single operation, particularly, in a first
            operation in a subsector. The errors and inconsistencies in
            presentation of the project development objective (PDO) and
            the gaps in performance indicators obscured the links
            between interventions and objectives in the SEEP, and
            hindered project implementation. Statements of a
            project's development objective should be clear,
            logical, and consistent, ideally, repeated verbatim across
            project documentation and throughout the course of project
            implementation. Key performance indicators should reflect
            all of the main elements of the PDO. The 2010 project
            restructuring was seriously late in reflecting changing
            implementation circumstances. Even then it did not address
            disconnect between the new activity, upgrading general
            secondary schools, and the project description and PDO
            instruments. The restructuring was also directed to senior
            management, without a documented consideration of whether
            circumstances may have warranted Board approval. In order to
            be the constructive tool that it is meant to be, project
            restructuring needs to be timely and appropriately directed.

repnme.cdata!:
Egypt - Secondary Education Enhancement
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Secondary Education Enhancement Project (SEEP) for Egypt is
            to establish the basis for an equitable education system by
            improving the quality and opportunity in secondary education
            through: a) increasing access to general secondary education
            through upgrading commercial schools to technological
            general schools and providing flexible options for study
            within and between branches of the system; b) better
            aligning curricula and assessment with the skills needs of
            employers and higher education; c) providing professional
            development for teachers and administrators on new
            technologies, curricula, assessment and management
            techniques; and d) by strengthening institutional capacity.
            The project has disbursed a total of SDR34.79 million
            (US$53.66 million equivalent) and the reallocation will make
            it possible to fully disburse the project funds. During the
            last year, the project has made significant progress in
            completing and getting Ministerial approval of a Core
            Curriculum, rehabilitating project schools to bring them up
            to standards so they can be accredited by the by the
            National Quality Assurance and Accreditation Authority
            (NQAAA) according to a recent quality initiative undertaken
            by the Ministry of Education (MOE); equipping schools with
            multipurpose science and computer labs; and training
            teachers, school principals, school managers and members of
            the education boards. The reallocation is necessary to
            complete the rehabilitation of project target schools which
            in turn will help these schools meet minimum infrastructure
            standards required for accreditation by the NQAAA.

repnme.cdata!:
Egypt - Secondary Education Enhancement
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Secondary Education Enhancement Project (SEEP) for Egypt is
            to establish the basis for an equitable education system by
            improving the quality and opportunity in secondary education
            through: a) increasing access to general secondary education
            through upgrading commercial schools to technological
            general schools and providing flexible options for study
            within and between branches of the system; b) better
            aligning curricula and assessment with the skills needs of
            employers and higher education; c) providing professional
            development for teachers and administrators on new
            technologies, curricula, assessment and management
            techniques; and d) by strengthening institutional capacity.
            This restructuring paper seeks the approval of the Regional
            Vice President (RVP) to extend the closing date of the
            project by four months from June 30, 2012 until October 31,
            2012. The SEEP was presented to the Board on April 15, 1999.
            The credit agreement was signed on April 19, 1999 but only
            became effective on June 29, 2000. The change is in response
            to a request from the Government of the Arab Republic of
            Egypt to extend the closing date from June 30, 2012 to
            October 31, 2012. If granted this will be the fourth closing
            date extension for this project. The extension is necessary
            to complete the rehabilitation of additional 67 schools
            during the summer so they can meet minimum quality
            requirements for accreditation and thus help achieve the
            project's quality of education objectives.

repnme.cdata!:
Egypt - Secondary Education Enhancement
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Secondary Education
            Enhancement Project for Egypt is to improve the quality and
            opportunity in secondary education. The project has
            disbursed a total of SDR30.75 million (US$47.66 million
            equivalent) and the reallocation will make it possible to
            fully disburse the project funds. During the last year, the
            project has made significant progress in equipping schools
            with multipurpose science and computer labs, and training
            teachers, school principals, school managers and members of
            the education boards. The reallocation is necessary to
            complete the rehabilitation of project target schools. This
            will help these schools meet minimum infrastructure
            standards required for accreditation by the National Quality
            Assurance and Accreditation Authority according to a new
            education quality initiative undertaken by the Ministry of
            Education (MOE). This reallocation will help meet the
            quality improvement objectives of the Project such as better
            alignment of the curriculum with the needs of the labor
            market, upgrading schools and improvement of teachers' skills.
